confession.seduction_context: On road to Baccarat when angry that her husband sent her out against her will. Told him she was angry and her children were very hungry. First time refused him although he offered money; second time agreed.
sabbat_activities: playing quilles using heads of stillborn children as boules and limbs as quilles

testimony.threat_quote: those who lived in his house were always ill

testimony.quarrel_subject: Wife had quarrel in market over payment for grain

reputation 9 or 10 years, that she was witch like her mother, who had been executed

18 months before, when living in house next to her

economic_context.details: Accused owed money to Demenge Mongeon (15 gros). She had sold grain to Nicolas Jean de Flin's wife. Economic tension around small transactions (milk, chaff, wood, grain). Husband described as potter who 'made very bad household'. She kept a tavern at some point. Prior court appearance for theft of cloth.

Debt payment of two cartloads of wood
Accused had been in court for stealing a piece of cloth

Master brought her grease in eggshell for transportation to sabbat
Faulty pot sold to wife of le Grand Colin
Devil's money turned to leaves and straw; refused as alms

prior_legal_disputes.description: Admitted she had been in court before for her part in stealing a piece of cloth

hearsay_chains.content: She disappeared for more than an hour, all dishevelled and with face bruised, as if coming back from sabbat

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: His cow had licked 'saumure' then drunk too much - natural cause
His wife was 'une meschante femme et une desdisse'
Alleged she had seen Marie stealing grain
Marie came to house and said it was a brothel and accused hid her husband in bed

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a thorough trial record with 62 witnesses. Key features: (1) Accused's mother was previously executed as witch, creating intergenerational pattern. (2) Economic status assessed as 'poor' based on debt disputes, husband's poor household management, children being hungry, prior theft conviction, and requests for alms. (3) Healing practice indicated: accused used yellow powder to try to heal Claudon Lhuillier, and the calf recovered after accused spoke to it. (4) Notable detail about sabbat activities including playing quilles with body parts of stillborn children - this information came from accused overhearing her mother's conversation. (5) Confession only came under torture (rack), withstood thumbscrews. (6) Many witnesses testified only to reputation (some spanning 12 years), suggesting long-standing community suspicion. (7) Pattern of quarrels over small economic transactions (milk, chaff, grain, small debts) followed by misfortunes. (8) Devil's money turning to leaves and straw is classic folkloric motif. (9) Accused showed some resistance, denying charges and offering natural explanations before torture. (10) Change de Nancy consulted twice: approved interrogation/confrontation on Nov 19, approved torture on Dec 4, approved death sentence on Dec 12.
